Introduction.content:
In the small village of Mcheche, everyone knew one man: Bwana Haraka. He was called Haraka because he was always running. Running to work, running to church, running to the shop, running to the toilet. But somehow, he was still late for everything.

One day he bought the newest phone in Dar es Salaam – a shiny Samsung Galaxy Ultra Mega Plus. He loved it more than his own children. He even kissed it goodnight.

Little did he know… this phone had a very strange habit.

Chapter 1.chapter_title: The Day the Phone Discovered Chapati
Chapter 1.content:
Bwana Haraka woke up at 5:45 AM (which was sleeping in for him). He grabbed his fresh chapati from Mama Ntilie, put on his shoes, and ran out the door.

While running to the daladala stand, he took out his new phone to check WhatsApp. The phone slipped, fell straight onto the chapati, and… CHOMP!

![Shocked man watching his phone eat chapati](https://picsum.photos/seed/phone-eating-chapati/800/600)

The phone ate the entire chapati in 3 seconds flat.

Bwana Haraka screamed, 'Wewe! My breakfast!' The phone just showed a smiling emoji and said, 'Yummy' on the screen.

Chapter 2.content:
The next morning, Bwana Haraka was smarter. He put the chapati in a plastic bag, tied it with seven knots, and held it in his teeth while running.

He took out the phone to take a selfie. The phone saw the chapati in his mouth and… ZOOM! It flew out of his hand, bit the chapati through the plastic, and swallowed everything – plastic, knots, and all.

Now the phone started burping notifications: 'Burp… new message… burp… low battery.'

The whole daladala laughed until they cried.

Chapter 3.chapter_title: The Phone Joins WhatsApp Food Group
Chapter 3.content:
By the third day, the phone had joined every food WhatsApp group in Tanzania: 'Mama Lishe Specials', 'Keki za Arusha', 'Nyama Choma Deals', even 'Vegans Tanzania' (it was very confused that day).

Every time someone posted a photo of food, the phone would vibrate, open its camera, and try to eat the screen.

Bwana Haraka’s boss sent a message: 'Come to office NOW!' The phone saw the word 'now' and thought it was 'naan'. It ate the message and replied with crumbs.

He got fired by autocorrect.

Chapter 4.chapter_title: Village Meeting: Should We Ban Bread Near Phones?
Chapter 4.content:
The village elders called an emergency meeting under the mango tree.

Mzee Koba said, 'This phone is a danger to society! Yesterday it tried to eat my mandazi while I was video-calling my grandson!'

Mama Fatuma added, 'It stole my child’s biscuit during online classes!'

They passed a new law: 'No bread, chapati, mandazi, or vitumbua within 2 metres of Bwana Haraka’s phone.'

The phone read the new law and sent a crying emoji to the village admin.

Chapter 5.chapter_title: Mr Hurry vs Samsung – The Final Bite
Chapter 5.content:
Bwana Haraka decided enough was enough. He went to the shop in Kariakoo and shouted, 'I want my money back! This phone eats everything!'

The shopkeeper laughed. 'Sir, that is the new Samsung Galaxy Hunger Edition – specially made for Tanzania. It runs on chapati power!'

Bwana Haraka had only one choice left. That night he made 50 chapatis, stacked them like a tower, and left the phone on top.

In the morning… the phone was gone. Only a thank-you note remained:

![Empty plate with a thank-you note and phone crumbs](https://picsum.photos/seed/empty-plate-crumbs/800/600)

'Thank you for the best week ever ❤️ Now I am fully charged for 10 years!'

Conclusion.content:
From that day, Bwana Haraka stopped running. He walks slowly now, eating his chapati peacefully before touching his phone.

And somewhere in phone heaven, there is one very fat, very happy Samsung that never needs charging again.

The end.

(But sometimes at night, people in Mcheche village still hear a quiet burp coming from the sky…)
